newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Perstorp sees 27 pct fall in yr profit.
newsitem.headline: Perstorp sees 27 pct fall in yr profit.

text.p: Chemicals company Perstorp AB on Tuesday forecast that its full year profit would fall by about 27 percent after posting a 21 percent drop in pre-tax profit for the first eight months.

Perstorp forecast a pre-tax profit of 500-550 million crowns after restructuring costs for the year ending September 30, 1997, compared to a pre-tax profit of 716 million crowns in the same period a year earlier.
For the eight months to April 30, Perstorp reported a pre-tax profit of 362 million crowns against 456 million crowns a year earlier.
"On the whole business conditions and demand were strong during the period in North America and Asia, where the positive trend for chemicals and flooring products continued," Perstorp said.
"In Europe, there have been signs of an improved business climate in recent months, but demand continues to be weak, particularly in construction and plastic-related operations."
Perstorp said the situation in the chemicals market was more varied.

The company said the sale of Perstorp Components and Perstorp Analytical cut operating income in the eight months to 7.78 billion crowns from 8.55 billion but its continuing operations posted a favourable volume increase.

Perstorp said for the full year, its current operations were expected to report improved earnings before non-recurring items compared with a year ago, forecasting a pre-tax profit to about 550-550 million crowns.

"However the net of capital gains and restructuring measures, in a total amount of about 125 million crowns ($16 million), will have a negative impact on full-year earnings, as will a reduction in positive currency effect compared with the preceding year," Perstorp said.
This forecast corresponded to earnings per share of 6.98-7.68 crowns, down from 10.00 crowns a year earlier.
"The group's cost cutting and rationalisation programme is expected to have a positive impact on earnings as of the next fiscal year," Perstorp said.

It was referring to a programme to cut costs by 500 million crowns over a three year period and to organise the company into three divisions; Perstorp Chemicals, Perstorp Surfaces and Perstorp Plastics Systems in addition to the business development company Pernovo.
At 1150 GMT Perstorp shares were two crowns lower at 123 crowns.
